variant.question: A SIGMET

options.text: is a warning of meteorological hazards in the FIR for all aircraft.
is a route forecast, issued several times during the day by the Met Offices.
reports the actual weather of an airport every 30 minutes.
is added as a short-term forecast to the actual weather report of an airport.

variant.question: A clearway

options.text: all of the above.
may be water.
provides an area over which an aeroplane can safely transit from lift off to the required height.
need not have the same weight bearing qualities as the runway with which it is associated.

variant.question: During flight, the pilot notices that he/she does not have enough final reserve fuel. The aircraft is 40 minutes away from the departure (A) and 50 minutes to the destination (B). There is a runway of another aerodrome (C) in sight but ATC reports that the weather is below minimum. What should he/she do?

options.text: Land at C.
Declare an emergency and ask ATC for further instructions.
Continue to B.
Return to A.

variant.question: Define the term 'screen height':

options.text: The height at the end of the take-off distance required and at the beginning of the landing distance required.
The required height to overfly mountains or mountaineous areas.
The minimum height above ground when passing the final approach fix.
The minimum ILS approach height when not performing a visual approach.

variant.question: What is V~D~?

options.text: The maximum tested airspeed where the aircraft is free from any signs of dynamic pressure overload, flutter, and/or control reversal.
The highest speed at which sudden, full elevator deflection (nose-up) can be made WITHOUT exceeding the design limit load factor.
A speed selected by the designer and used to assess the strength requirements in cruise.
A specially recommended penetration speed for severe turbulence.

variant.question: What is V~S1g~?

options.text: The 1-g stall speed at which the aeroplane can develop lift equal to its weight.
The stall speed or the minimum steady flight speed at which the aeroplane is controllable in 1-g conditions.
The speed at which onset of natural stall warning occurs with the aeroplane NOT exceeding 1-g conditions.
The speed at which onset of artificial stall warning occurs with the aeroplane NOT exceeding 1-g conditions.

variant.question: In twin engine aeroplanes with propellers turning clockwise as seen from behind:

options.text: the left engine is the critical engine.
the minimum control speed is determined by the failure of the right engine.
the right engine is the critical engine.
the left engine produces a higher yaw moment if the right engine fails than vice versa.
